chapter.title: Get it running
chapter.subtitle: Curtains up!
chapter.para: Now we had a pretty complete application. It was time to put it to the test.

section.title: Populating the database
section.para: Before we opened the gates we needed to add some movie data. So we wrote a small class for populating the database which could be called from our controller. A simple /populate endpoint for the controller that called it would be enough for now.

example.title: Populating the database - Controller

section.para: Accessing the URI we could see the list of movies we had added.

section.title: Inspecting the datastore
section.para: Being the geeks we are, we also wanted to inspect the raw data in the database. Reading the Neo4j docs, there were a couple of different ways of going about this.

section.title: Neoclipse visualization
section.para: First we tried Neoclipse, an Eclipse RCP application that opens an existing graph store and visualizes its content. After getting an exception about concurrent access, we learned that we have to use Neoclipse in read-only mode when our webapp was still running. Good to know.

section.title: The Neo4j Shell
section.para: For console junkies there was also a shell that was able to connect to a running Neo4j instance (if it was started with the enable_remote_shell=true parameter), or reads an existing graph store directly.

The shell was very similar to a standard Bash shell. We were able to cd to between the nodes, and ls the relationships and properties. There were also more advanced commands for indexing, queries and traversals.

example.title: Neo4j Shell usage
